search_result.title: 20 politically incorrect songs that'd be wildly controversial today
search_result.text:
There's nothing like hearing a song come on the radio or flicker across a Spotify playlist that you haven't encountered in a while, and realizing, "Was this song always this offensive?"

The answer: Yes, it probably was. Standards have changed quite a bit in terms of what references the culture at large deems offensive in its hit songs, from casual homophobia in pop songs from Katy Perry and Taylor Swift to the jaw-dropping lyrical content of some Rolling Stones classics.

Below, find a list of songs that, if released today, would almost certainly ignite a scandal.

Song: Kung Fu Fighting by Carl Douglas, 1974

Choice lyric: “There was funky Billy Chin and little Sammy Chung / He said ‘Here comes the big boss, let’s get it on.' ”

Why it wouldn't fly today: Perhaps the song was just trying to celebrate the ancient art of kung fu. But its lyrics about “funky Chinamen from funky Chinatown” with stereotypically Asian-sounding last names isn’t exactly a nuanced appreciation of the culture.

Song: Brown Sugar by the Rolling Stones, 1971

Choice lyric: “Gold coast slave ship bound for cotton fields / Sold in the market down in New Orleans / Scarred old slaver knows he's doing alright / Hear him whip the women just around midnight.”

Why it wouldn't fly today: Even Mick Jagger knows these lyrics aged incredibly poorly; in recent years, he’s changed the words when he performs the song live. Beyond the song’s opening stanzas, the racism, misogyny and outright references to raping slaves make this a low point in the Stones’ discography.

Song: Under My Thumb by the Rolling Stones, 1966

Choice lyric: “Under my thumb, the squirmin' dog who's just had her day / Under my thumb, a girl who has just changed her ways."

Why it wouldn't fly today: Another disgusting entry in the Stones’ songbook, the song about a woman who’s been molded to “talk when she's spoken to” is an embarrassment for even existing.

Song: Ur So Gay by Katy Perry, 2007

Choice lyric: “I can't believe I fell in love with someone that wears more makeup and / You're so gay and you don't even like boys”

Why it wouldn't fly today: If Perry’s I Kissed A Girl was borderline gross for its exploitative take on same-sex experimentation, Ur So Gay crosses the line with its deeply immature rattling-off of gay stereotypes, driven home by the use of the word as a slur.

Song: Picture to Burn by Taylor Swift, 2008

Choice lyric: “So go and tell your friends that I'm obsessive and crazy / That's fine, I'll tell mine that you're gay.”

Why it wouldn't fly today: Perry’s frenemy Taylor Swift wasn’t immune to the same kind of sophomoric homophobia, with Picture To Burn subscribing to the same backward view that the worst thing you could call a teenage boy is “gay.”

Song: Do They Know It’s Christmas? by the Band Aid choir, 1984

Choice lyric: “And there won't be snow in Africa this Christmas time / The greatest gift they'll get this year is life / Where nothing ever grows, no rain or rivers flow / Do they know it's Christmas time at all?”

Why it wouldn't fly today: Possibly the most culturally insensitive Christmas song of all time, the Band Aid supergroup may have raised money to alleviate an Ethiopian famine with the proceeds from Do They Know It’s Christmas. But they did it with a song that declares the entire continent of Africa is bereft of water, trees or joy.

Song: Turning Japanese by The Vapors, 1980

Choice lyric: "I'm turning Japanese, I think I'm turning Japanese"

Why it wouldn't fly today: No, Turning Japanese isn't literally about turning Japanese. Still, it wouldn't be acceptable today to hear a group of white guys assuming the identity of Asian people.

Song: I'm an Indian Outlaw by Tim McGraw, 1994

Choice lyric: “You can find me in my wigwam / I'll be beating on my tom-tom / Pull out the pipe and smoke you some / Hey and pass it around.”

Why it wouldn't fly today: McGraw is certainly not “an Indian outlaw, half Cherokee and Choctaw” as he claims in the song. And even if he were, that wouldn’t excuse the hilariously lazy Native American tropes he employs.

Song: Island Girl by Elton John, 1975

Choice lyric: “Island girl, what you wanting with the white man's world / Island girl, black boy want you in his island world”

Why it wouldn't fly today: The borderline fetishization in John’s chart-topping ode to a New York City prostitute who’s “black as coal but she burn like a fire” is cringeworthy.

Song: Ebony and Ivory by Paul McCartney and Stevie Wonder, 1982

Choice lyric: “Ebony and ivory / Live together in perfect harmony / Side by side on my piano keyboard / Oh lord, why don't we?”

Why it wouldn't fly today: McCartney and Wonder meant well with their hyper-literal interpretation of race relations. But their message of “people are the same, there’s good and bad in everyone, so let’s just get along” would be interpreted as hilariously naïve by the more woke factions of today's cultural discourse.

Song: Rape Me by Nirvana, 1993

Choice lyric: “Rape me / Rape me, my friend”

Why it wouldn't fly today: We get it. Kurt Cobain was a deeply tortured soul. He probably, in retrospect, could’ve expressed this one better.

Song: Tonight’s the Night (Gonna Be Alright) by Rod Stewart, 1976

Choice lyric: “Don’t say a word, my virgin child, just let your inhibitions run wild"

Why it wouldn't fly today: In case the lyrics to this No. 1 hit weren’t cringe-inducing enough, try not feeling icky watching its video. In it, Stewart woos a faceless young woman and leads her up to his bedroom before she says in French, “I’m a little scared. What is my mother going to say?”

Song: One in a Million by Guns N' Roses, 1988

Choice lyric: “Immigrants and f****ts, they make no sense to me / They come to our country and think they’ll do as they please"

Why it wouldn’t fly today: Axl Rose attempts to win our sympathy with his story of a “small-town white boy” feeling lost when he moves to Los Angeles. But using derogatory language for gay and black men certainly doesn’t help his case, nor do his wildly xenophobic lyrics about immigrants. (“They talk so many (expletive) ways / it’s all Greek to me.”)

Song: Kissin' Cousins by Elvis Presley, 1964

Choice lyric: "Well I've got a gal, she's as cute as she can be / She's a distant cousin but she's not too distant with me"

Why it wouldn't fly today: Nothing like a little casual incest to get the crowd up and dancing. This seemingly innocent but actually creepy doo-wop tune is taken from the King's 1964 movie musical, in which he plays an Air Force pilot whose two beautiful cousins compete for his affections. Different times?

Song:Age Ain't Nothing But a Number by Aaliyah, 1994

Choice lyric: "Age ain't nothing but a number / throwing down ain't nothing but a thang / This lovin' I have for you, it'll never change"

Why it wouldn't fly today: No disrespect to the late Princess of R&B, whose hypnotic vocals and idiosyncratic style remain timeless. But it's hard not to feel at least mildly uncomfortable listening to this song in retrospect: At the time she recorded it, a then-14-year-old Aaliyah was dating — and would soon illegally marry — her mentor/producer R. Kelly, who was 27.

Song: Illegal Alien by Genesis, 1983

Choice lyric: "It's no fun being an illegal alien"

Why it wouldn't fly today: Its message and story are seemingly well-intentioned, detailing a Mexican immigrant's struggle to cross the border in search of a better life. But the racist video puts the song in a whole different light, with stereotypical imagery of mariachi horns, ponchos, sombreros and oversize mustaches.

Song:Walk on the Wild Side by Lou Reed, 1972

Choice lyric: "Holly came from Miami, F-L-A / Hitchhiked her way across the USA / Plucked her eyebrows on the way / Shaved her legs and then he was a she"

Why it wouldn't fly today: In a song filled with racy anecdotes, this reference to Holly Woodlawn, a transgender actress who was bullied as a teenager and ran away from home, is alarmingly tone-deaf.

Song: Money for Nothing by Dire Straits, 1985

Choice lyric: "See the little f****t with the earring and the makeup? / Yeah buddy, that's his own hair / That little f****t got his own jet airplane / That little f****t, he's a millionaire"

Why it wouldn't fly today: A slight at effeminate rock stars, once again using "gay" as an insult. It's no wonder this homophobic slur was omitted from the band's greatest-hits album, Sultans of Swing.

Song: Dude (Looks Like a Lady) by Aerosmith, 1987

Choice lyric: "She had the body of a Venus / Lord, imagine my surprise / Dude looks like a lady"

Why it wouldn't fly today: Guy walks into a bar and realizes the stripper he's been ogling is actually a man. Although the rock classic was co-written by openly gay songwriter Desmond Child, its questionable use in the media — by Fox News when reporting on Chelsea Manning, for instance — makes us think that it's not the homage to the LGBTQ community that he intended.

Song: He Hit Me (It Felt Like a Kiss) by The Crystals, 1962

Choice lyric: "He hit me and it felt like a kiss / he hit me and I knew he loved me"

Why it wouldn't fly today: Gerry Goffin and Carole King were inspired to write the doo-wop ballad by the tragic true-life story of singer Little Eva, who told them that her boyfriend's beatings were motivated by love. But without context, lyrics such as "he hit me and I was glad" are an off-putting endorsement of domestic abuse.

search_result.title: Taylor Swift's 'Lover' turns 2: A love letter to her lost triumph
search_result.text:
You’d be forgiven if the first thing you thought about Taylor Swift’s seventh studio album "Lover" was the same as its first track: "I forgot that you existed."

Sure, the album made a splash when it premiered two years ago on Aug. 23, 2019 (she celebrated the anniversary Monday by joining TikTok), and peaked at No. 1 on the Billboard 200. Bubbly singles "Me!" and "You Need to Calm Down" were a far cry from Swift'sdarker "Reputation" era. Third and fourth singles "Lover" and "The Man" solidified Swift’s next chapter as one of happiness, maturity and self-determination.

Then, about six months later (before her "Lover Fest" tour could take off), the COVID-19 pandemic took over the world and canceled crowded live music events.

That didn’t stop Swift from creating music, though. In July 2020, about a year after "Lover," she debuted "Folklore" (which went on to win the Grammy for best album of the year), followed by sister album "Evermore" in November 2020. And then there's her "Fearless (Taylor's Version)" re-recording, which dropped in April, and upcoming "Red (Taylor's Version)," due Nov. 19.

But what happened to "Lover" in all the hubbub of Swift’s new woodland nymph era and blasts from the past? Nothing, and that’s exactly the problem.

"Lover" stands the test of Swiftian time as her lost masterpiece, an ode to love in all its forms – and one we could surely use right now as we cap off yet another cruel summer.

And more albums to come:Taylor Swift reveals new tracks for 'Red' album after teasing fans: 'Congrats pals'

The 'Lover' era represented a simpler time we'd love to return to

You won't hear any complaints here about the woodsy, cottage-core vibes of "Folklore" and "Evermore," but Swift's loud, colorful and bold looks from the "Lover" era felt daring and carefree in a way we're longing to return to.

The glittery release of "Lover" came about six months before COVID-19 changed the world. The splashy aesthetic seeped into Swift's music videos ("Lover" and "You Need to Calm Down") as well as her merchandise (we lived for the pastel-centric Stella McCartney fashion collaboration).

As much as we love the muted vibes of "Folklore" and "Evermore," living amid the prolonged pandemic makes us nostalgic for the time when solving problems felt as simple as "step(ping) into the daylight and let(ting) it go."

Our review:Taylor Swift is a kid again on 'Lover,' a big, messy embrace of a new album

We'll always walk down 'Cornelia Street'

While "Lover Fest" never happened, Swift treated us to live performances before the pandemic. We can't stop playing one in particular: The "Cornelia Street (Live from Paris)" recording from her "City of Lover" one-day concert at Paris' Olympia theater. Fans hardly recognized the start of the stripped-down version of the song, but once they did, screams bellowed out from the crowd and they sang along.

Live performances can sometimes sound better than the album recordings – and we'd argue that's the case here. Something about this version's raw energy and Swift's connection to her audience breaks our heart a "Lover Fest" tour never happened. But it also makes us that much more excited for whatever concert she'll concoct for us next.

We'll walk "Cornelia Street" again and again with you, Taylor.

Queen celebrates queen:Taylor Swift gushes over Simone Biles’ Olympics return: ‘We all learned from you’

'Cruel Summer' should have been a single

The aforementioned four singles Swift chose summed up the vibe of this era: Confident and in love but ready to take down anybody who gets in her way or of someone she cares about.

Aside from being a certified bop, "Cruel Summer" represented Swift's duality as a songwriter. Yes, she's in a steady relationship that prompts beautiful love ballads, but she can also still write a killer song about new relationship anxiety.

It's a song that deserves to go down in Swift's bridge hall of fame (as does this album's "Death By A Thousand Cuts"). Add to the list of song lyrics we wish we could have belted out during "Lover Fest": "I don't wanna keep secrets just to keep you/And I snuck in through the garden gate/Every night that summer just to seal my fate/And I screamed for whatever it's worth/'I love you,' ain't that the worst thing you ever heard?"

Some fans crossed their fingers that "Cruel Summer" would be released the following summer as a post-album single (which Swift has previously done with "You Belong With Me," "Red" and "Style") and maybe even a music video. Instead, she dropped a whole new album in the summer of 2020 as the world faced a truly cruel summer.

Two albums later (or three, if we're counting "Fearless (Taylor's Version)," we know Swift is busy with her re-records and has moved on from her "Lover" days. But we'll still scream our hopes that "Cruel Summer" gets its due, for whatever it's worth.

search_result.title: Kanye West's 'Jesus is King' new gospel album, film are holy but ...
search_result.text:
Another Kanye West album is here, and with it, another collective shrug of indifference.

"Jesus is King," the rapper's most clear-cut foray into Christian hip hop, was released midday Friday after multiple delays and tracklist changes. The 11-song, 27-minute album finds West teaming up once again with frequent collaborators including Pusha T, Ty Dolla Sign and producer Mike Dean, as well as his recently formed Sunday Service collective: a gospel group that has accompanied him throughout the past year at Coachella music festival in April and various pop-up shows nationwide in months since.

In some regards, "Jesus is King" is West's riskiest effort yet. Here, he completely abandons his provocative rhymes about fame, women and mental health, and potentially alienates longtime fans with chaste lyrics about God, heaven and staying on the straight and narrow. Interpolating Bible verses and Christian hymns, and frequently backed by a church organ and choir, the album suggests a bold new direction for the now-father of four (a musical path he looks to continue on with the just-announced "Jesus is Born," out Christmas Day.)

So why can't we get more excited about it?

There was a time when new music from the rap legend felt like an event. Who can forget the thrill when, after widespread backlash to the Taylor Swift incident at the 2009 VMAs, he emerged from hiding a year later with "My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy," his grandiose career-defining masterpiece (and arguably the best album of the past decade)? The messy rollouts and bold swings of 2013's "Yeezus" and 2016's "The Life of Pablo" kept fans on their toes, even if in retrospect, we weren't nearly critical enough of West's offensive and unwanted depictions of Swift and other female celebrities on the latter.

More:Kanye West slams Kim Kardashian's tight dress as 'too sexy'; Tyler Cameron offers defense

But in the past couple of years, West's antics have grown increasingly tiresome. Last year's "Ye" – which he unveiled during a star-studded listening party in his new adopted home of Wyoming – felt sporadic and unfinished; an afterthought to the string of albums he would produce and feature on for other artists that summer. His blind support of President Donald Trump and attempts to reclaim the "Make America Great Again" hat as a symbol of unity have been ignorant and misguided, while his bizarre insistence last year that slavery was a "choice" just seemed like faux provocation for the sake of it.

In terms of elaborate rollouts, "Jesus is King" is West at his most exhausting. The rapper made a 31-minute IMAX film to accompany the album, which is screening in theaters nationwide for one week only. Shot with obnoxious fish-eye lenses and shown almost entirely through circular frames, the movie mostly lingers on long shots of billowing clouds, wildlife and the backs of choir singers. West appears only in silhouette to perform a God-focused update of "808s & Heartbreak" track "Street Lights," which serves as an emotional finale to an otherwise self-indulgent and unnecessary project.

More:Kanye West's 'Jesus is King' inspires mosh pits, strong emotions at LA preview event

"Jesus is King," the album, doesn't fare much better. Lyrically, the music sounds as if West picked up a Bible yesterday, took everything at face value and decided to make an album about it. His rhymes are often lazy and on the nose, making broad declarations about his new outlook on life since finding religion. ("Thou shalt love thy neighbor, not divide," he raps on "On God." "His light shine the brightest in the dark.")

He extols the power of forgiveness and counts himself among God's soldiers on "Selah," and repeatedly asks for guidance and protection throughout "Use This Gospel," which reunites rap duo Clipse and features a saxophone solo from none other than Kenny G. "Closed on Sunday" warns against the dangers of social media and vanity, and opens with one of West's most cringe-worthy lyrics to date: "Closed on Sunday, you my Chick-fil-A," referring to the famously religious fast-food chain, which has donated to anti-LGBTQ groups through the years.

More:Taylor Swift slams Kanye West in Rolling Stone interview: 'He is so two-faced'

More: Christian hip hop is having a moment: 6 rappers you should know, including chart-topper NF

West's trademark wit is largely absent from "Jesus is King." ("What if Eve made apple juice?" is the clearest attempt at humor on "Everything We Need," but his mixed metaphor about partaking in sin ultimately goes nowhere.) And while the production is reliably stellar, there are no standout hooks that make any of these songs worth returning to.

This is in no way meant to discredit West's recent religious awakening. Many of us will go on spiritual journeys throughout our lives, and if finding God has given him inner peace, there's no reason he shouldn't reflect that in his music. But most everything on "Jesus is King" feels purely surface level, devoid of any of the soul-searching or introspection that faith often brings.

The only exception is "God Is," a searing confessional in which West exorcises his demons in real time. Appearing to reference his past struggles with opioid abuse, he thanks the Lord for "freedom from addiction," and expresses gratitude for his family and health.

"This my kids, this the crib / This my wife, this my life / This my God-given right," West breathlessly chants, his voice audibly cracking and aching as he races to the song's finish. "Thank you, Jesus, won the fight."

It's a powerful example of someone being profoundly moved by spirit, and a reminder that West still has the ability to move us.

search_result.title: Marilyn Manson's 'We Are Chaos' gets a shot from Shooter Jennings
search_result.text:
Like most of Marilyn Manson’s previous releases, his new “We Are Chaos” is good music for Halloween. And in a year blighted by a worldwide pandemic, his material is all the more appropriate for 2020.

Manson hits the familiar marks here with metal-draped rage, industrial-sized rhythms and histrionic posturing delivered with monster-modulated vocals and acidic lyrics.

Shooter Jennings is the surprise weapon: The alt-country star produced or co-produced (with Manson) every track on the release. The two previously worked together on a song for an unlikely 2016 Jennings album that paid tribute to electronic-music/disco icon Giorgio Moroder, though “We Are Chaos” fits snugly in the Manson oeuvre, with a Bowie-esque glam rock edge that likely owes something to Jennings.

Yet this is mostly Marilyn Mason just being Marilyn Manson, whether he’s swimming through the saturated framework of the title track to find an anthemic payoff, striding through the grind of “Red Black and Blue” with the hook “Am I garbage or God?” or chugging along in the dramatic spin of “Don’t Chase the Dead” to offer the advice, “Don’t chase the dead, or they’ll end up chasing you.”

Unlike others in the hard/industrial/death/rock/metal subgenres, Manson delivers his venom with his tongue in cheek, and he hits irresistibly accessible highs, as when he commandeers the crushing dance cadence of “Perfume” to offer the winking warning, “If you conjure the devil, you better make sure you got a bed for him to sleep in.” He also fits snugly in the surreal power-ballad mode of “Paint You With My Love”

Manson ventures over a lot of familiar territory on “We Are Chaos” and sounds a little tired at times (you try being Marilyn Manson for 30 years), but he offers a satisfying and sneering explanation on the track “Solve Coagula”: “I’m just broken, and I don’t wanna be fixed.”

Marilyn Manson

"We Are Chaos"

Rating: 3-1/2 (out of 5)

++++++++++

Guyton gets somewhere on 'Bridges'

Thirty-something years ago, Mickey Guyton was growing up in small-town Texas, listening to Dolly Parton tapes with her grandmother and falling in love with classic country music. She sounds like countless other Southern girls with Grand Ole Opry dreams, but as she sings on her new song “Black Like Me,” “I did my best just to fit in.”

Guyton has lived her dream of being a country singer, though in a genre dominated by men – and especially white men – she isn’t a household name. But that could change, or at least her profile should grow, with her new “Bridges,” a disarmingly honest EP that is infectious, poignant and (mostly) country.

Produced by Karen Kosowski, the release is authentic, opening with a prayer for an ailing society on the infectious power ballad “Heaven Down Here” and then segueing to a title track where Guyton sings “we’re gonna need more than prayers and wishes” to put out the fire on the street.

Guyton is genuine, soulful and charismatic. She’s straightforward, but hopeful, and unifying, not divisive.

“What Are You Going to Tell Her” is heart-wrenching, a piano-based reality check for parents of color who try to foster their children’s hopes, yet “do you let her think the deck’s not stacked?” And on the moving “Black Like Me” she makes a plaintive pitch: “If you think we live in the land of the free, you should try to be black like me … I know I’m not the only one who feels like I don’t belong.”

Heavy and beautiful as these songs are, Guyton also has a wicked playful side, evident in the Western showdown of “Salt” (“You think you’re getting’ sugar, but boy you’re gettin’ salt”). Plus, on the giddy toast to her favorite beverage, “Rose,” Guyton sounds like Parton, chirping, “Pretty in pink, baby that’s my kind of drink!”

Now that’s country.

Mickey Guyton

"Bridges"

Rating: 4 (out of 5)

++++++++++

Brian's '1999' hits the spot in 2020

Rich Brian is at his worst when he’s at his technical best and at his best when he’s at his technical worst on his new “1999.”

The 21-year-old Los Angeles-based vocalist from Jakarta, Indonesia, rips through the rapid-fire rap of the track “Long Run” in a dazzling display of speed and an absolute lack of personality as he dispenses a lot of words that don’t say much against the thumping bass and tinny synthetic sweeps.

By contrast, in the woozy vibe of “When You Come Home,” Brian is all over the map – uneven, imperfect and completely endearing in the dreamy arrangement, offering lines like, “You always make me laugh when you speak/And you always thought my laugh was funny.”

Brian is impressively dexterous here, writing and producing on a handful of tracks that range from the strident nervous energy of “Don’t Care” to the oddly spiritual-esque melancholy of “Sometimes,” where he says his life is like the movies because “I skip the drama and get right to the action.”

Brian is also a singer, taking a page from The Weeknd in the sleek synth/dance of “DOA” to sing, “Nights like this could make the brightest days overrated,” and later protecting himself on “Sins” with, “I can’t let your sins just take away my faith.”

Plus on the uncharacteristic pop song “Love in My Pocket,” Brian shows his agility by singing and rapping through wry ambivalence and amusing twists.

Brian is barely 21 and “1999” is only seven songs long, but he shows more range here than most artists twice his age with twice as many songs … even if the speed rapping is gratuitous.

Rich Brian

"1999"

Rating: 4 (out of 5)

++++++++++

Richie unearths her comedic side

It should be no surprise that fashion designer/actress/celebrity Nicole Richie would get around to making an album: Her father is Lionel Richie, her husband is Good Charlotte lead vocalist Joel Madden, and even her onetime bestie Paris Hilton has indulged in making music. But nearly everything else about Nicole Richie’s new “Unearthed” – which is credited to her alternate persona, Nikki Fre$h – is a surprise.

“Unearthed” is comedy rap, a Lonely Island-ish “conscience trap album” where Richie plays an overly woke pro-environment troubadour.

The release features half a dozen “voicemails” where friends and associates (and Lionel Richie himself) are baffled by her new persona and try to talk her out of releasing the album.

But here it is, with the mother of two warning her kids not to “bring the Virgo out in me” on first song “Parent Trap” (and telling them to “go do your homework”) before she turns her attention to nature.

She frets over the loss of honeybees on “Bee’s Tea” (“I’m just tryin’ to save a queen”), worries about rejected not-traditionally-attractive fruits and vegetables on “U.G.L.Y.” (“We take damn good food, and we kiss it goodbye”), advocates for clean water on “Drip Drip” (“Everything requires water and so do me”) and recognizes kindred spirits in plant life on “We Are a Garden” (“A kumquat tree … an epiphany … it’s just like me”).

The standout track is “Lil Gems,” a well-executed modern dance song about the power of gems to repel negative energy. And there’s an extended spoken track, “Knuckle Fresh,” where Nikki visits a senior living home to give away her music and receptive resident Trixie says, “We have literally nothing to do and all the time in the world.”

Fans of eccentric diversions might find time for “Unearthed,” too.

Nikki Fre$h

"Unearthed"

Rating: 3-1/2 (out of 5)

++++++++++

Sweeping tones compensate for vocals

Suburban Living bridges shoegaze music to the sweeping tones of Gothic rock on its new “How to Be Human,” creating thoughtfully ornate soundscapes suitable for reflection, rumination and/or relaxation by its listeners.

The Philadelphia by way of Virginia Beach band builds its textured sound on layers of guitars from Wesley Bunch and Chris Radwanski plus Radwanski’s keyboards and the rhythm section of drums by Mike Cammarata and bass by Peter Pantina.

The tracks sprawl with effective disembodiment, typically elevating in intensity on each track, though the shifts are subtle. The resulting psychological impact of “How to Be Human” is primal as the thick arrangements sink into the psyche and absorb into the soul.

But there’s an all-too-human aspect to the release: Bunch’s vocals are subpar, weakly navigating through the swarming instrumentation and serving as a mildly irritating distraction to the aural effect. His words are spiked with passion, but Bunch’s mundane and hookless vocal delivery sinks into the mix, corrupting the lyrical intent.

The words do bleed through – whether on the lush city-themed “Main Street,” where he sings, “I look to you in my time of need … I’m begging you, please let me in,” or when he wonders in the insinuating intoxication of “Video Love (T’s Corner),” “Is this my time?”

Apart from the occasional tedium that surfaces on a few songs, “How to Be Human” compensates for the vocals with the music, as when Max Swan steps in with a saxophone solo in the flooded sound of “Indigo Kids” or when the indulgent 7-minute arrangement of closer “Once You Go” pays off with an evocative atmosphere.

If only the vocals were better, “How to Be Human” could have been transcendent.

Suburban Living

"How to Be Human"

Rating: 3-1/2 (out of 5)

++++++++++

Cools finds 'Paradise' in California

Musicians are often inspired by locations for their material, and so it is with Evelyn Cools on her California-based “Misfit Paradise,” which explores a time in 2018 when she “experienced love like she never had before,” according to a press release.

Despite some lyrical references to the state and Southern California folk-rock leanings in the arrangements, however, “Misfit Paradise” seems far more informed by that unprecedented love experience, which comes off as elusive, potentially obsessive and also both blissful and oddly threatening.

Cools – a native of Belgium who lived in London, Budapest and Hong Kong before moving to the United States – starts strong on “Misfit Paradise” with the starry-eyed piano ballad “Another Night,” where she wonders, “What if we never met? What if I never said, ‘Could I come over, I want to know you better?’” Later, on the bucolic “Yosemite,” where Cools sings in the measured style of an old folk song until she gives way to distant feral wails by song’s end, she issues the invitation, “The howling winds are calling me/Meet me at Yosemite.”

The title track is the messiest song on “Misfit Paradise,” with the vocalist’s delivery not enough to take over a largely uneventful, if over-complicated, arrangement as she sings lines like, “the only way we know is never to let go.” On the flipside, the rocking “Gold Woman” might be the tightest track, alive and raw as she sings of a femme fatale only to pivot to a confession that she’s a “gold woman” herself.

Yet the acoustic-guitar-driven closing cut “Soaring” is the best overall representative of “Misfit Paradise” as Cools struggles to articulate her intense feelings: “It’s hard to explain the grip you’ve got on me/It’s hard to explain everything I fear.”

Sometimes love is like that.

Evelyn Cools

"Misfit Paradise"

Rating: 3-1/2 (out of 5)

++++++++++

Katy Perry offers humble 'Smile'

Katy Perry may get knocked for sticking to formula on her new “Smile,” but it works.

Perry’s last release – 2017’s “Witness” – was abysmal, an attempt at something innovative and “purposeful” (Perry’s word) that was soulless, overproduced and overlong. On the final track, she sang the symbolic line, “No one’s ever seen me like this,” and it’s doubtful many would want to see her like that again.

The humble “Smile” – released within days of the birth of her daughter, Daisy – is an about-face. Like Lady Gaga’s retreat from art pop into her comfort zone earlier this year with “Chromatica,” Perry is blithely unassuming, breaking no ground and visiting familiar territory.

Although nothing overwhelms, there are several highlights. Perry’s audience can be swept along with the muscled rhythm of “Cry About It Later” as the singer goes drinking, contemplating a new tattoo and looking for a new love: “I think I’m ready to be someone’s new muse.” She’s equally confident in the ticking timebomb of “Resilient” (ready to grow “right through the cracks”), playful in the plucky tropical R&B diversion of “Harleys in Hawaii” and determined in the swooping aural storm of “Teary Eyes.”

And unlike the ill-fated closer of “Witness,” “Smile” punches out with a grandiose “What Makes a Woman,” a self-assured anthem about learning to love yourself.

Much of the rest of “Smile” is fairly forgettable, though never bad, with Perry forcing the drama with fits of oversinging, accompanied by snappy pop and EDM-blasted arrangements.

Perry has said in interviews that “Smile” was her effort to put a dark time behind her, and it sounds like she did.

Not every album has to change the world.

Katy Perry

"Smile"

Rating: 3-1/2 (out of 5)

++++++++++

Braxton's 'Name' is (mostly) healthy

Toni Braxton’s new “Spell My Name” feels like a healthy break-up album at first.

Busted relationships can be a mess, sometimes driven by devastating heartbreak, desperate attempts at reconciliation and relentless rage. Yet at the onset of “Spell My Name,” Braxton is where she needs to be, with a little bitterness and a lot of pride fueling her resolve to move on.

The stirring groove of buoyant opening cut “Dance” is all she needs to deliver a kiss-off to a fresh ex, employing her robust vocal with dignified restraint: “Tonight you’ll see I won’t be lonely.”

Subsequent tracks follow a similar theme: Missy Elliott pops in for some sass on the rich call of “Do It” (a unifying anthem to support women who need to break away from a bad relationship), Braxton navigates the unhurried strings and hefty textures of “Gotta Move On,” and “Fallin’” adds a gorgeous context for a biting send off.

But on the fifth song, “Spell My Name’s” title track, there’s a pivot as Braxton plies the suggestive swirling rhythms and percolating percussion to make a play for a younger man.

Then Braxton simply spins out in all directions – stuck in the limbo of a half-broken relationship on the intoxicating “O.V.E.Rr.” and swamped by ambivalence on the slow sprawling “Saturday Night.” Meanwhile, standout track “Happy Without Me” is a showcase of excruciating heartbreak, with Braxton pouring on the passion with wrenching despair.

“Spell My Name” closes with the earthy soul of “Nothin’,” which finds our hero reduced to rubble with the sobering realization, “Without your love, I ain’t nothin’.”

It’s a heartfelt, albeit disappointing, finale, but that’s the way love goes.

Toni Braxton

"Spell My Name"

Rating: 4 (out of 5)

++++++++++

Georgas confronts 'All That Emotion'

Hannah Georgas has used her immaculate voice as a vehicle for vulnerability. It’s clean and soft and inspires empathy for all the betas and introverts who are overpowered and overshadowed by alphas and extroverts. She can break a heart and prompt a chuckle with one line.

The Canadian singer-songwriter treads into even darker territory on “All That Emotion,” which suits the title with ambivalence – resentment, resolve, frustration, anger and something more sinister as she confronts what could be lovers, friends, relatives, or perhaps all of the above, who have held the upper hand, manipulated her and left her feeling helpless and untrusting.

No, this isn’t a traditional breakup album.

Working with producer Aaron Dessner, Georgas creates a more fleshed out sound for her electronic-based arrangements, and the restless rhythms and muted frenetic touches serve to underscore her anxious lines, though her voice is soothing, save for palpable ache on mesmerizing closing track “Cruel.”

In the percolating cadence and meditative strains of “Easy,” Georgas contemplates how a dead relationship can transform the soul, on the sweet-sounding “Same Mistake” she calmly notes, “I grew up in a family of wolves,” and on “Pray It Away” she wonders, “Will you still love me even though I’m not what you thought?”

It’s weighty material and beautifully executed. Listeners may long for more of the dry humor and higher energy that Georgas has employed in the past, but that wouldn’t have been appropriate on most of these songs.

Besides, there’s a refreshing truth at the core of “All That Emotion,” and when Georgas dovetails with the ginger rhythm of opening cut “That Emotion” – singing, “Hide behind all that emotion/See how long, how far, you can keep going” – it’s an oddly liberating challenge.

Hannah Georgas

"All That Emotion"

Rating: 4 (out of 5)

++++++++++

Morissette's lyrics offset shortcomings

Alanis Morissette released her groundbreaking “Jagged Little Pill” 25 years ago, and now she releases a “Such Pretty Forks in the Road” that is simply grounded.

Yes, it’s a letdown, a musically monotonous string of unadventurous arrangements that could use more hooks and shimmer. But it’s also a platform for Morissette’s trademark introspective thoughts.

So, while “Such Pretty Forks in the Road” is short on sing-along choruses and aural dazzle, the 46-year-old Morissette compensates with moody monologues about middle-age life – in her case, with a focus on motherhood and complex relationships shaded by the residual damage of abuse.

“This is the sound of me hitting bottom,” she warns on opening cut “Smiling” that hints at a darkly sedate Lana Del Rey vibe, but without mystique or sensuality. Subsequent songs are dominated by piano with flourishes of strings as Morissette offers loving warnings and encouragement to her children on “Ablaze,” ponders the elusive keys to successful relationships on “Missing the Miracle” (“You see the figure skater, and I fear the ice is thin”) and grieves “the end of superwomaning” on “Losing the Plot.”

Morissette’s challenges are many, whether sheds concerns about the opinions of others as she collapses into a meltdown on “Diagnosis” (“I’m folding in on myself since I am out of order”), struggles with her paralyzing fear of change on “Nemesis” or falls victim to opportunists on “Pedestal.”

Yet her often-poignant thoughts are prone to underwhelm with flaccid sonics as their foundation. It’s not a deal-breaker because Morissette is still that intriguing provocateur she was in her alt-rock 1990s. But it could have been more persuasive.

Alanis Morissette

"Such Pretty Forks in the Road"

Rating: 3-1/2 (out of 5)

++++++++++

Producer highlights deserving singers

Hitmaking producer Ricky Reed – who has worked with the likes of Lizzo, Halsey and Twenty One Pilots – puts out his own album with the new “The Room,” though he still throws focus on his guest vocalists.

It’s a smart move: His revolving cast of singers are an underappreciated group of talented performers who deserve a boost to their exposure. Plus, it’s still clearly Reed’s album, his aesthetic of glossy R&B blended with discrete electronic touches and warm jazz creating a signature sound that gives “The Room” smooth continuity.

And for their part the vocalists are distinct, though they complement each other in Reed’s finessed sound.

After free-floating through the ambience of opener “Shipwreck,” “The Room” brings aboard new singers with every song, and many unpack emotional baggage. There’s romanticism weighted by separation in the lush “Us (How Sweet It Was),” featuring Duendita and My Morning Jacket’s Jim James, and Godfather666 is uneasy in the lonely soul of “No Future” (where he wonders, “How can anybody love me?”).

Elsewhere, Malaya dovetails with the busy percussion and throbbing riffs of “In a New Place,” urgently noting, “I ain’t got no time for your words or your games,” and John-Robert and Alessia Cara offer coy humor on their flirty duet “Fav Boy.”

“The Room” also cooks up a heated vibe for “Real Magic” (featuring Terrace Martin and St. Panther) and classic R&B for “Better” (featuring Leon Bridges and Kiana Lede), and Ayoni’s sumptuous delivery brings “The Room” to a spiritual-esque close with “No Stone.”

Lyrically, “The Room” is fairly barren, and the well-executed atmosphere sometimes feels more important than the passion of the vocalists. But overall, it’s a sophisticated and engaging package.

Ricky Reed

"The Room"

Rating: 3-1/2 (out of 5)

++++++++++

Erasure is half-lit on 'Neon'

U.K. duo Erasure – aka Andy Bell and Vince Clarke – has been making pop songs on both sides of the Atlantic since the 1980s, though its last release, 2017’s “World Be Gone,” was a marked diversion, a dispirited collection of serious songs that broke from form and came across as clunky.

But the act’s new “The Neon” is a celebration of ’80s synth-pop, and at least half of the duo is fully invested.

Clarke’s production is crisp, synthetic confections that lovingly throw back to the dance floors and airwaves of decades ago. He creates a rolling hook for opener “Hey Now (Think I Got a Feeling),” shifts to the up-tempo percolation of “Fallen Angel,” churns through the gripping groove of “Shot a Satellite” and hitches to springy infection on “Diamond Lies.” And as usual, Clarke’s instrumentation is packed with nuances, decorative touches that dovetail with and add contrast to melodic backing vocals.

Unfortunately, Bell’s vocals, which have in the past matched Clarke’s energy and enterprise, is a tougher sell. Perhaps he still feels drained from the darkness of “World Be Gone,” maybe his voice has aged into a lower range that doesn’t rise to Clarke’s peaks, or it could be that the well-intended-but-often-superficial lyrics don’t inspire him.

Whatever, Erasure’s momentum routinely dips, and Bell is the cause, whether he’s fading in the subtle textures of “Nerves of Steel,” overshadowed on “Tower of Love” or lost in the uneventful “Careful What I Try To Do.”

At least Bell also turns it up, bringing vocal zest to the brighter arrangements (for example singing on “Diamond Lies,” “I’ve gotta stop pretending I can be that guy … Gotta wash my hands of you”) and supplying sincerity to the lesser material, as when he transcends his own awkwardness on “New Horizons” to sing, “When all is lost, don’t you ever give up hope/There will be new horizons/We will live to love again.”

Given Erasure’s long history, you have to believe him.

Erasure

"The Neon"

Rating: 3-1/2 (out of 5)

++++++++++

Halestorm reimagines itself

Hard rock band Halestorm has a history or recording EPs of cover songs in between releasing their full-length albums, but with “Reimagined” they mix it up: They cover their own songs.

Fans of the bracing Pennsylvania band might be apprehensive to hear the group has stripped down their songs for the new renditions, but they shouldn’t worry: Frontwoman Lzzy Hale has never been one for subtleties, and she makes up for any instrumental restraint with blunt (sometimes too blunt) firepower.

Hale carries the newly R&B-flavored “I Get Off” with blistering lines like, “I get off on you getting off on me” as she boils into full fury on the bridge. Her passion is also at the helm of the plaintive “I Miss the Misery,” and Hale bellows and wails through the strident drama of a retro-stadium-anthem version of “I Am the Fire,” asking, “Am I brave enough? Am I strong enough?”

Fellow rock belter Amy Lee of Evanescence joins Hale for a new take on “Break In,” turning the song into a raspy duo, an empowering statement of mutual support – which with a bit more finesse could have been a convincing throwback to the Wilson sisters of Heart.

There’s also an audacious cover of “I Will Always Love You,” which isn’t nearly as moving as the original version by Dolly Parton or the powerhouse rendition by Whitney Houston, but the Parton-penned song’s stately beauty nevertheless shines through.

“Reimagined” comes to life at the end with “Mz. Hyde,” Hale glowing in the added voltage to bask in the electric crunch, bringing a feisty sense of character to the song that doesn’t show as prominently elsewhere on the EP.

That closing track underscores the fact that though “Reimagined” is an interesting diversion, Halestorm is simply better with all guns blazing.

Halestorm

"Reimagined"

Rating: 3-1/2 (out of 5)

++++++++++

Brandy makes an eccentric return

“Sorry for the tardy” sings Brandy on “Saving All My Love,” the first track on her new “B7” – the singer’s first release in 8 years. It’s a curious track, with Brandy showing rich nuance with her now-41-year-old voice as she skirts along the irregular rhythm, merging with the music and vocalizing multiple voices as she also declares “I ain’t saving all my love for you.”

Brandy has been missed in the pop/R&B world, yet her return is odd, refreshingly anti-formulaic most of the time and strangely both intimate and obscure. It’s a personal journey that is only clear in flashes.

From the sweeping effects and electronic bloops of “Unconditional Oceans” to a swirling duet with her teen daughter Sy’rai (where Brandy uses her rap alias Bran’Nu), “B7” is comfortably erratic.

For her part, Brandy is also all over the place, luxuriating in the pretty strains of “No Tomorrow” while singing “When you stare at me I feel so beautiful,” funneling an angry rasp over the jazzy piano of “Say Something” to rage, “You take back promises, where did they go?” and accentuating the electric jabs of “I Am More” by declaring she “can’t be the other woman … I need more ’cause I am more.”

Brandy also drops in references to mental health, sadly battling deep insecurities on the humming “Borderline” with “Don’t wanna be schizo this time” and bashing a bad beau on “Bye Bipolar” with a spiritualistic combination of bitterness and humor (“I lost your ring, and you can keep your last name”).

There are also accessible and rewarding duets with Daniel Caesar (“Love Again”) and Chance the Rapper (“Baby Mama”), which underscore the trippy and sometimes overly eccentric adventures elsewhere on the release.

“B7” is mostly a win, however, and hopefully enough to motivate Brandy to forego another disappearing act.

Brandy

"B7"

Rating: 4 (out of 5)

++++++++++

Swift matures on subtle 'Folklore'

Taylor Swift is 30 years old and several years deep into what appears to be a satisfying relationship with British actor Joe Alwyn. Not coincidentally, her new “Folklore” simmers all of the fire, anger, joy and vindication of her previous albums into a sophisticated and quiet brew, markedly nostalgic and fueled by long-term undercurrents of emotion rather than fresh love or hurt.

“Folklore,” concocted by Swift in quarantine with help from The National’s Aaron Dessner and producer Jack Antonoff, is a boldly thorough departure in form, a gamble that her unwavering fan base will embrace it nonetheless, even if the tone is understated, free from pep … and honestly a bit overlong.

Yet it’s also the most consistent of her eight albums, packed with confident and effective songwriting convincingly voiced by Swift and free from pop pandering (not to shade those wildly infectious hits from her past).

Listeners will be swayed from her one-two opening punch of tearjerker songs “The 1” and “Cardigan,” the former a mellow heartbreaker with a wistful Swift mourning a lost relationship with someone who should have been “the one,” and the latter a soft-rumbling and poignant tale: “When I felt like I was an old cardigan under someone’s bed, you put me on and said I was your favorite.”

There are no flops on the release that also finds Swift taking the role of a corpse seeing her tormentor at her funeral (“My Tears Ricochet”), remembering an endangered childhood friend in the gorgeously gauzy “Seven,” tortured by the ache of unrequited infatuation (“August”) and enchantingly broken in the folkish “Mirrorball.”

And perhaps in a nod to her unsettled days, Swift closes the release with “Hoax,” where she flails helplessly in the grip of a poisonous relationship: “I am ash from your fire.”

“Folklore” didn’t need a dance song.

Taylor Swift

"Folklore"

Rating: 4-1/2 (out of 5)

++++++++++

'Dreamland' shimmers with surrealism

"Dreamland” is an absorbing trip into emotional otherworldliness from the U.K. band Glass Animals.

The group layers synth-pop and hip-hop elements to create a luxurious, yet relatively delicate, atmosphere enhanced by frontman Davy Bayley’s high, and melodically inviting, vocals.

It’s an elusive brew, with rays of truth arcing out of a fanciful foundation, and the effect can be narcotic.

The shimmering title-track opener sets the tone for connection in a stay-at-home world – “You’ve had too much of a digital love/You want everything live, you want things you can touch,” sings Bayley. And much as society takes on a surrealistic air when its members are self-isolated in their safe spaces, “Dreamland” labors away in an altered state. It’s akin to taking hallucinogens at a crowded festival; sharing the moment, though your experience is yours alone.

There’s an intoxicating flow in the infatuation-based “Hot Sugar,” hazy minimalism in the peculiar break-up-themed “Melon and the Coconut” and a commanding beat loop for “Waterfalls Coming Out Your Mouth.”

The themes are provocative – like when Bayley rides the compressed teeter of “Space Ghost Coast to Coast” to address a childhood friend who plotted a mass killing, or when he assumes the role of a child whose mom is abused by his dad on “Domestic Bliss,” and pleas with her to escape with him: “Fight for me.”

Even Bayley’s relationship songs are complicated, such as when the mutually self-destructive pair on the booming “Your Love (Déjà Vu)” prove hellbent on normalizing chaos, and “It’s All So Incredibly Loud” is about the point of no return in a doomed relationship, the moment when one person fatally wounds the bond with a statement that can’t be retracted.

“Dreamland” may not be lucid, but it’s rewarding for the adventurous.

Glass Animals

"Dreamland"

Rating: 4 (out of 5)

++++++++++

Deborah Silver shines on 'Glitter'

Deborah Silver’s new “Glitter & Grits” is a breezy joy, an inventive spin on classic songs from the “Great American Songbook” that serves as a respite from a pandemic year. And Silver knows firsthand about COVID-19: She contracted it and had to spend 58 days in isolation from her family.

She has since recovered, however, and is actively promoting “Glitter & Grits,” which she made with the help of producer Ray Benson of the Texas swing band Asleep at the Wheel. Benson brought along bandmates to the project, too, putting the “Grits” in these renditions of the standards.

“Glitter & Grits” does more than just swing: It’s flush with other strains of jazz and Americana, awash with the nostalgia of these familiar songs and cushioned by the mildly restrained theatrics of Silver’s delivery.

What’s more, the Everly Brothers’ “Let It Be Me” is recast into something unsettling and trippy, Vince Guaraldi’s “Cast Your Fate to the Wind” veers into cartoonland, and Tom Jones is revamped twice – in a swarm of buzzing faux hornets on “Delilah” and an obstacle course of glitchy nuance on “Love Me Tonight.”

Yet the sound is a blast even further back, to the likes of surf rock and 1960s girl group material, though shaded with a wry edge that brings to mind early Blondie albums before all the No. 1 hits started rolling out.

Then there’s Juniper at the center, a “normal” 15-year-old girl armed with smart lines about falling for a boy at an amusement park (“The Dragon Coaster”), falling in line to fall for the magnetic Chad (“Everybody’s Got a Crush on Chad”), falling for a bad boy in tight jeans (“Punk Rock Boy”) and refusing to fall for all the enticing boys who aren’t her stable boyfriend (“Sticking With My Henry”).

She waltzes through an R&B-styled “Girls Just Want a Boy to Rest Their Head Upon,” tries to resist her dreamboy in the psychedelic “I Don’t Want to Dream About You” and fusses that “Dreaming about you is taking all of my time” on “Best Kept Secret.” Plus, the title of “Boys! Boys! Boys! Boys! Boys!” speaks for itself.

The relentless boy-crazy themes are kinda ugh, but you be you, girl.

And Juniper does branch out: The jumpy “Kids on My Corner” is a gleeful blast about a local band that “wrote a song/It’s not that good, but it’s not that long.” And “Gotta Draw the Line” is about her undying devotion to her BFF, whom she would do anything for … er, unless she flirts with Juniper’s boyfriend.

Still, despite the narrow focus, “Juniper” is a smart and rewarding release.

Juniper

"Juniper"

Rating: 3-1/2 (out of 5)

++++++++++

Peter Manos will get in your head

Peter Manos is fast-tracking his slow-lane style in the music business with his new debut EP, “Do You Turn Red?”

In 2017 the Texas native was eyeing a music career while studying at Nashville’s Belmont University when he created the song “In My Head” in his dorm room. The brooding, quiet number hinges on lines filled with regret and sadness like, “You say it’s all alright, but you’re not the one who’s up at night.”

The song went on to be streamed hundreds of millions of times, including more than 100 million times on Spotify alone while also generating almost 70 million views on YouTube.

It was enough to prompt Manos to move to Los Angeles, where he created a home studio to record “Do You Turn Red?” And as sparse as “In My Head” is, the other songs on the EP are almost subliminal.

Manos creates a distinct air in this minimalistic, electronic-based marvel, compounding the woozy instrumentation with indistinct, albeit soulful, enunciation and the somber vibe of downbeat lyrics that dwell in disappointment.

The chilled environment is surreal and lowkey mesmerizing, whether Manos is reverberating in the smoky realm of “My Mind,” glowing through the gorgeous translucence of “Zach’s Ballad” or slow-dripping emotion in the cool “You Don’t Know Me,” where he sings, “I don’t think you know me like you thought you did.”

“At Night” employs a thickened sound, a relatively dense foundation that creates more impactful support for his lonely vocals, and the swirling tonic of “Tennessee” finds his modulated vocals meandering through a soundscape of compressed bass as he realizes, “Nothing ever changes and nothing ever changes … and I wish I could change this.”

Compared to the other songs, the gentle EP closer “In My Head” sounds downright lively.

Never underestimate the power of understatement.

Peter Manos

"Do You Turn Red?"

Rating: 4 (out of 5)

++++++++++

Chiasm gets carried away

Longtime darkwave star Chiasm, aka Emileigh Rohn, gives a taste of her upcoming album “Missed the Noise” with a new EP, “Away.”

The Detroit-based performer has put out some austere material the past 20-something years, industrial-drenched noise explosions and implosions, but “Away” is considerably more accessible thanks in part to her collaboration with John Fryer, producer for the likes of Depeche Mode and Nine Inch Nails.

“Away,” featuring four distinctly different mixes of “Away,” is actually accessible from four different directions.

The original mix is a dramatic, hard-rubbed-synthesizer brand of electro, a Goldfrapp-meets-Grimes instrumental context for the vocals of Rohn, who at times sounds like a dead ringer for the Bangles’ Susannah Hoffs (of all people). The subsequent “Interface Remix” of the song rides a thumping dance beat and rolling electronic pulses plus piano-esque nuance – ideal club music that reverberates with Rohn’s refrain, “Why don’t you take me away?”

Later, a “Skydeck Mix” of “Away” puts the song in sleek-stalker mode, an NIN-reminiscent blend of alt-rock foreboding with suggestions of quiet horror that create an impenetrable mystique. Then a “GW4 Mix” of the song takes the insistent rhythm into a lowkey, electronic-chill mode, the vibe merging with lines about “our lives are churning away, our hearts are churning away …”

For good measure, the EP closes out with a “:10:” mix of the song “Frantic,” a less-inviting track than any of the versions of “Away” as it disintegrates in the collapsing crunch of an electric fire.

That closing cut may be a memento to hardcore fans who feast on Chiasm’s artful tangents, but the cornucopia of “Aways” on the EP show broader promise for her next move.

Chiasm

"Away"

Rating: 4 (out of 5)

++++++++++

Berger's "Moon" proves enlightening

Calling Mare Berger’s new 8-song “The Moon Is Always Full” a chamber-pop EP doesn’t begin to describe it.

The jazz-trained performer doesn’t merely sing along to easily digestible string-and-piano arrangements. Instead, the composer/vocalist/pianist creates a provocative alternate universe that basks in a mind-bending assortment of philosophical and existential observations and suggestions, and the tracks are shaded in a range of genres outside the traditional chamber-pop realm.

But sure, there are strings.

“The Moon Is Always Full” opens with a somewhat strident “Even When We Forget,” with lines like “We are the ocean, we are the drop … Even when we forget, we are … We are everything.” From there, Berger’s pure voice rings out in “Step Away My Dear,” singing, “When we think we know, we know nothing.” Subsequent lines include the mantra “I pray that the seed will grow” on the title track and on the less ornate “Praise This Fear,” “Praise this fear that holds me down … Praise this fear that makes me, me.”

The latter track has a spiritual air in its clean mix, but other songs display markings of rock (e.g. Lilith rock) and folk (especially indie or alt-folk), and the meditative “Stardust” sounds like an old mountain ballad. Meanwhile, the instruments, especially the strings, are often employed in aggressively experimental bursts to keep listeners alert.

There’s also a complicated, ever-shifting “Wondering” that pivots and builds into what sounds like a Jane Siberry mini-musical from the 1990s, Bergen asking, “When does a person become a thought? … What does a memory mean?” The release then moves into its swooning finale, “You Are Within.”

It’s hard not to be temporarily absorbed into Berger’s realm (even if some of the lines sound more like smart bumper stickers than profound thoughts), yet why resist?

Mare Berger

"The Moon Is Always Full"

Rating: 4 (out of 5)

search_result.title: The ultimate guide to what's free in Europe
search_result.text:
Jamie Ditaranto

SmarterTravel.com

When you're sightseeing, there are things you don't mind paying for, and then there's this list — the things you don't have to pay for at all.

THE NETHERLANDS

Amsterdam

Museums: For free museums in Amsterdam, there's the Civic Guard Gallery and the Multatuli Museum, which gives a look inside one of Amsterdam's grand canal houses and was home to the famous Dutch writer.

Landmarks: Visit the 15th-century church Nieuwe Kerk, or take a free tour at the Gassan Diamond Factory. You can also catch free music at Bimhuis on Tuesdays and at Concertgebouw on Wednesdays.

Best views: For a high-up view of Amsterdam, head to the top floor of the Central Library, which is open to the public. You can also check out the Sky Lounge at the DoubleTree hotel to get a great view (but you will have to buy something at the cafe).

UNITED KINGDOM

London

Museums: If you're looking for culture in London, you're in luck. The city's top museums (including the National Gallery, the Tate, the Natural History Museum and the British Museum) are all free.

Landmarks: The House of Parliament, St. Paul's Church and Temple Church.

Best views: Take in the sights at Parliament Hill, the Royal Observatory or the Skygarden, which requires advanced booking but is ultimately free.

Music: Head to Westminster Abbey any day at 5:30 p.m. to catch the Evensong. When the choir sings, you don't have to pay.

Edinburgh

Museums: Stroll along Edinburgh's Royal Mile to enjoy the National Museum of Scotland, the Edinburgh Writers Museum, Museum of Childhood, Museum of Edinburgh and the People's Story, which are all free.

Landmarks: Take a free tour of Scottish Parliament or discover St. Giles' Cathedral.

Best views: Calton Hill, Arthur's Seat.

Music: Free entry at Whistle Binkies, the best place to check out Scotland's up-and-coming bands.

FRANCE

Paris

Museums: While in Paris, you can check out the Museum of Modern Art for free, and if you happen to be in the city on the first Sunday of each month or Bastille Day (July 14) then entry to the Louvre is free, too.

Landmarks: If you're looking for free sights, try the Sacre Couer Basilica, Montparnasse Cemetery or Arenes de Lutece.

Best views: For the best and totally free view of Paris, head to Parc de Belleville.

Nice

Museums: Nice offers plenty of free art with free entry at the Museum of Modern and Contemporary Art, the Chagall Museum and the Matisse Museum.

Landmarks: Monastere de Cimiez offers both a beautiful building and gorgeous view of Nice.

Best views: For another fantastic view that only requires a little bit of hard work, explore Castle Hill.

PORTUGAL

Lisbon

Museums: With the exception of its temporary exhibitions, the Berardo Collection Museum is free. Also be sure to the check out the Electricity Museum, housed in an old power plant.

Landmarks: Save your sightseeing day for Sunday, because that's the day when all city attractions in Lisbon are free.

Best views: Viewpoints in Portugal are often referred to as miradoura, and you can find them all over the city. Check out Miradouro de Sao Pedro de Alcantara overlooking Baixa, and then Miradouro de Santa Catarina.

SPAIN

Madrid

Museums: While entry to the Bullfighting Museum is free every day, you'll have to time it just right to take advantage of a free ticket at the city's other museums. You'll find free entry the Prado between 6:00-8:00 p.m. Monday through Saturday and the Reina Sofia Monday through Friday from 7:00-9:00 p.m.

Landmarks: Templo de Debod is an authentic Egyptian temple donated to the city in 1972. Inside, you'll get close enough to touch the ancient walls and explore the mini-museum showing the temple's origin. It's completely free.

Best views: The Temple of Debod also happens to be located in one of the parks with a great view — Parque del Oeste. For another free park with amazing views, you can check out Cerro del Tio Pio.

Barcelona

Museums: Free museums are harder to find in Barcelona, but if you wait until Sunday, all museums offer free entry.

Landmarks: To see a renovated market with deep history, check out El Born Centre Cultural. Entry to La Catedral is also free in the early morning and late afternoon.

Best views: If you're up for a hike, amazing views can be seen from the top of Tibidabo Mountain. You can also take in the city from the Montjuic Castle, which is free on Sundays after 3:00 p.m.

GREECE

Athens

Museums: Athens is full of museums with free entry, including the Kanellopoulous Museum, Museum of Greek Popular Instruments, Epigraphical Museum Centre of Folk Art & Tradition and many modern art museums.

Landmarks: In a city as ancient as Athens, the ruins and landmarks are hard to miss, and some of them are free. Check out the National Gardens, Aristotle's Lyceum, Antonis Tritsis Park, Syntagma Square, Hadrian's Arch, Temple of Olympian Zeus and the Panathenaic Stadium.

Best views: Getting the best views of Athens takes a little walking. Hikes up Lycabettus Hill or Filopappou Hill will pay off with gorgeous free views.

ITALY

Rome

Museums: Many of the public museums and archeological sites in Rome can be enjoyed for free on the first Sunday of each month, such as the Vatican Museums and the Gallery of the National Academy of San Luca. If you won't be around for the first Sunday of each month, you can visit the historic Liberation Museum, where you'll be able to learn about Rome's long process of gaining liberation from the Nazis.

Landmarks: Many of Rome's most beautiful cathedrals are free of charge, such as St. Peter's Basilica and Basilica di Santa Prassede. And if you're looking for a colossal experience without the price of entry into the Colosseum, Teatro di Marcello is a great way to experience ancient Roman architecture without the crowds.

Best views: Jaw-dropping views of Rome cost nothing more than a short hike. Many hills around the city offer stunning vantage points for free, such as Janiculum Hill, Capitoline Hill, Palatine Hill and the Garden of Oranges located behind the Basilica of Santa Sabina.

DENMARK

Copenhagen

Museums: There are many free museums to enjoy in Copenhagen where you can learn about Danish history and art, such as the Danish National Gallery and the National Museum of Denmark.

Landmarks: Enjoy a free stroll through the city's Botanical Garden and check out the famous statue of Hans Christian Anderson's Little Mermaid.

Best views: Take advantage of free entry at Christiansborg Palace and climb the tower at the King's Gate entrance for sprawling views of the city.

TURKEY

Istanbul

Museums: In Istanbul, you can enjoy free entry at the Istanbul Modern and the Haglia Sophia Museum, or go gallery-hopping down Istiklal Street.

Landmarks: The majority of mosques in Istanbul offer free entry, but you'll have to be careful to avoid prayer times in which you won't be allowed to enter, such as the Blue Mosque and Eyup Sultan Mosque. And if you tire of mosques, you can always visit the Basilica Cisterne or explore the Grand Bazaar and Hipodrome Square for free.

Best views: Head to Suleymaniye Mosque and Complex to get the best views of the city.

GERMANY

Berlin

Museums: Seeing the Berlin Wall at the East Side Gallery is always free, but if it's raining there are many free indoor museums to visit, such as the historical Anti-War Museum and literally obscure Museum of Unheard of Things. (See the full list here.)

Landmarks: Aside from its museums, Berlin doesn't offer much more for free admission, but fortunately there are still many outdoor attractions like Checkpoint Charlie, Brandenburg Gate, and the Holocaust Memorial that you can explore without charge.

Best Views: To get the best free view of Berlin, take the elevator to the top of the Reichstag to view the city from the iconic dome. You'll have to book in advance, though, and it is not possible to book over the phone.

Munich

Museums: Unfortunately, Munich doesn't offer much in terms of free museum admission, but you can pay a discounted price of €1 to Museum of Man and Nature on Sundays.

Landmarks: You can visit the small but beautiful Asam's Church and take in the Glockenspiel show in the city center for free.

Best views: St. Peter's Church offers free admission and access to their tower, where you'll be able to take in expansive views of the city.

FREE FOR STUDENTS

It's worth noting that if you're studying abroad or just a student traveling in Europe, your student ID card will get you a long way. Double-check museums and landmarks for student discounts or free entry.

search_result.title: Most Visited Countries in the World – 24/7 Wall St.
search_result.text:
Cristabelle Tumola

24/7 Wall Street

It’s the end of January and travel enthusiasts are probably already planning their next big trip abroad. But where to? While Europe and Asia are still hot spots, some of the countries that people are crazy about have changed.

As global travel becomes easier and a burgeoning middle class in countries like China boosts travel to nations around the world, international tourism continues to grow. Popular tourist destinations, such as France and the United States, which are among the happiest countries in the world, still hold top spots among visitors, but countries like Spain are catching up.

In order to determine the most visited countries in the world, 24/7 Wall St. analyzed data on international tourism and number of arrivals in 264 countries between 1995 and 2016 provided by the World Bank. The number of international arrivals in 2016 was used to determine the most visited destinations. Data on population composition and 2016 tourism revenue comes from the World Bank, and Gross Domestic Product for 2017 from the International Monetary Fund (IMF).
